#newdaynewchapter ‚ÄúThough Saraswati is regarded as the Goddess of Learning, can Goddess Matangi be regarded as the Goddess of Learning?‚Äù Sri Matangi is one of the ten forms of the Goddess called Dasa-Mahavidya. The ten forms of the Goddess represent the 9 celestial bodies which form part of the astrological influences in one's life with the tenth representing the Ascendant at birth (the portion of the Zodiac rising in the East with reference to Lat-Long of place of birth). Sri Matangi represents the Sun and the medical sign Leo and three ‚Äúmansions of the stars‚Äù- the constellations Kritika, Uttara, Phalguni and Uttarashadha. The worship of Goddess Matangi is for enlightenment, enhanced presence (hence political/royalty recognition) and be a leader with adequate skills and power base for a fair and productive success. Gayatri is represented with the following five elements of Divine Nature. 1. Prithvi-Bhuta: Solid Matter/Element. 2 Apa-Bhuta: Water Element. 3. Agni-Bhuta: Fire Element. 4. Vayu-Bhuta: Air Element. 5. Akash-Bhuta: Divine Energy. She is also represented by ten arms, hands, and instruments. These ten instruments represent ten directions of the light of the Sun. She is also called Savitri, the consort of Savitur, the Sun-God. Hence, Gayatri Mantra is also in praise of Sun-God, the presiding deity of our Solar system. Fortunately, there is a connection between Goddess Saraswati in Goddess Gayatri. There are 3 forms of Goddess Gayatri. 1. Brahmani Gayatri: The chanting of Gayatri Mantra at 6 am facing east is dedicated to Goddess Brahmani Gayatri, the consort of Lord Brahma. Hence, she represents Goddess Saraswati. 2. Vaishnavi Gayatri: The chanting of Gayatri Mantra at noon facing north is dedicated to Goddess Vaishnavi, the consort of Lord Vishnu. This aspect can be related to Goddess Lakshmi. 3. Rudrani Gayatri: The chanting of Gayatri Mantra facing west is dedicated to Goddess Rudrani, the consort of Lord Shiva (Rudra). This aspect can be related to Goddess Parvati. Jay Ma Saraswati:

#newdaynewchapter It is said Hanumanji is the only avatar still roaming on earth. He is easy to be pleased. He is very dear and close to Shri Rama. So to meet Shri Rama it is always better to please hanuman. The story behind Hanuman Chalisa goes like this. Goswami Tulsidas was known as a very good astrologer before he wrote Ramayana. He gave a negative prediction for the Mughal king Akbar. The predictions came true and Akbar wanted Tulsidas to shift to his darbar which he refused. Akbar jailed Tulsidas. It was in jail Tulsidas started praying to hanuman and in the process he wrote Hanuman Chalisa. Chute bandi maha sukh hoi. Tulsidas ji was released within few days as Akbar realized his mistake. In all the stotra, Hanuman Chalisa the boon or Ashirwad which the related deity give always come in the end where as in Hanuman Chalisa it comes in the beginning. Bal buddhi vidya dehu mohi harau klaish vikar. Tulsidas knew the power and reliability of chalisa so he mentioned the benefits right in the beginning. Last but not the least hanuman is an avatar of Shiva. Prahalad the Chakravarti of kingdom of Bhaktas has told 9 types of Bhakthi towards the lord. Among them are the following two : Shravanam - Listening to the Lord‚Äôs stories, great deeds, and his divine qualities. Keertanam - Singing the Lord‚Äôs names all day long without wasting even a moment Both are equally good. Which is better depends on the person. Some like to listen while some like to sing. Follow your heart and choose. However, people may have different experiences and interpretations of the effects of religious or spiritual practices. It's important to remember that the impact of such practices can vary from person to person, and there's no universal rule. Although one thing is for sure, it makes you strong , your heart strong , if that is what you see as being emotionless, then maybe the answer to this is Yes! Jai Seeta Ram! Shri Hanuman Maharaj ki Jay.

#newdaynewchapter According to Akhand Sutra, Savitur is the Sun-God. Gayatri is the dynamic female form of the formless Brahman (Paramatma). Savitur and Gayatri are not the same. Goddess Gayatri is not the consort of Savitur. Let us first explore, enumerate, and explain the fundamental concept of Gayatri. Chandogya Upanishad (3.12.1), ‚ÄúGayantam Trayate iti Gayatri‚Äù means that the person, who chants (Gayantam) Gayatri Mantra, is protected (Trayate) by Gayatri. ‚ÄúTat, Savitur Varenyam, Bhargo Devasya Dhimahi, Dhio Yonah Prachodayat!‚Äù The meaning of the three sets of three words (nine words) of this mantra is as follows. Tat: It represents the Ultimate, Formless, Omnipotent, Omniscient, Omnipresent, and all-pervasive Universal Consciousness called Nirakar-Nirgun-Brahman (God-Nature-Paramatma), the source of everything in the universe. Nirakar-Brahman manifests as Sakar-Brahman, the core united male (Shakta) Trinity (Trimurti) form of Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva. This form is popularly called Sri Dattatreya. Nirakar-Brahman also manifests as the female dynamic form (Shakti) with the five heads, which represent the five elements (Panch-Bhutas), namely, 1. Prithvi-Bhuta: The solid form of Earth-Bhu-Bhumi-Bhur. 2. Apa-Bhuta: The fluid water form. It also represents Saraswati, Goddess of Knowledge. 3. Agni-Bhuta: The fire-heat-burning form. It represents Lakshmi, Goddess of Wealth. 4. Vayu-Bhuta: The air form (atmosphere-Bhuva). It represents Parvati, Goddess of Moksha. 5. Akash-Bhuta: The plasmatic quintessence form. It represents the enlightening heaven (Suvah). This manifested form of the unmanifested Brahman is called Goddess Gayatri. The three heads of Brahma, Vishnu, and Shiva form the core male form (Shakta). The five heads of Goddess Gayatri form the dynamic female form (Shakti). Goddess Gayatri with five heads represents the Universal Consciousness of Maha-Brahmand. Savitur: Savitur means the Sun. The second focus of Gayatri Mantra is the Sun-God, the presiding deity of our Solar system, and the energizer of the living beings on the earth. Our Solar system is called Brahmand, an egg-shaped system. It is the microcosmic representation of the macrocosmic universe (Maha-Brahmand). Varenyam: It means brilliant effulgence or light of Sun, the life-giving force. Bhargo: It means splendor of the seven beautiful colors, namely, violet, indigo, blue, green, yellow, orange, and red (VIBGYOR) of the Sun-light. Devasya: It means divine. The higher world of the Solar system is called Brahmand. Dhimahi: It means self-surrender to the higher divine kingdom of Nature. Dhio: It means seeking or asking for blessings, grace, and illumination. Yonah: It means the specific wish of enlightenment. Prachodayat: It means given, graced or blessed by three forms of Goddess Gayatri. Shri Gayatri Mataji ki Jay

#newdaynewchapter Sarvam Vishnnuhu - Everything is Vishnu (Universe) This means that the entire world is filled with Vishnu. The whole world is pervaded by Lord Vishnu- Bhaja govindam series. Imagine yourself watching a cinema in theater. It is common that you sit facing the screen and then feel impatient that the pictures are not appearing on the screen. After some time, pictures begin to appear on the screen and you feel happy. These pictures on the screen are continually changing. They do not remain permanently on the screen. The pictures that appear on the screen are Mithya. They are not permanent, but the screen is permanent. In this context, we should understand that the screen is real and the pictures are an illusion. The screen can be compared to Brahman. The permanent and all-pervasive Vishnu, and the impermanence of the world explain the true meaning of ‚ÄúSarvam Vishnu Mayam Jagat.‚Äù Vishnu Purana says ‚ÄòJyoteemshi Vishnuh ‚Äì all bright objects are Vishnu in character‚Äô. Swami Chinmayananda quotes the following verse ‚Äì ‚ÄúJale vishnuh sthale vishnuh vishnur_Akasam uchyate | sthavaram jangamam vishnuh sarvam vishnu-mayam jagat Meaning: ‚ÄúWater is Vishnu, every place is Vishnu, the sky is Vishnu. Every movable or immovable object is Vishnu. In short everything in the world is nothing but Vishnu.‚Äù Ultimately, we call the higher power which sustains this universe Vishnu and he is everywhere, because he is everything. ‡§â‡§§‡•ç‡§™‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§™‡•ç‡§∞‡§≤‡§Ø‡§Ç ‡§ö‡•à‡§µ ‡§≠‡•Ç‡§§‡§æ‡§®‡§æ‡§Æ‡§æ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§ó‡§§‡§ø‡§Æ‡•ç | ‡§µ‡•á‡§§‡•ç‡§§‡§ø‡§Ç ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Æ‡§µ‡§ø‡§¶‡•ç‡§Ø‡§æ‡§Ç ‡§ö ‡§∏ ‡§µ‡§æ‡§ö‡•ç‡§Ø‡•ã ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§®‡§ø‡§§‡§ø || He who understands the creation and dissolution, the appearance and disappearance of beings, the wisdom and ignorance, should be called Bhagavan. ‚Äî (Vishnu Purana, VI.5.78) Bhagavan means the Almighty God who is the controller of all opulences, power, fame, beauty, knowledge and renunciation. He is the protector of His pure devotees. Although God is equally disposed to everyone, He is especially inclined to His devotees. The word Bhagwan has symbolic meaning too. The word encompasses Earth, Water, Fire, Air and Space ‚Äì the five elements. Thus the term Bhagavan translates as the manifestation of the physical form of universe. In the word ‡§≠‡§ó‡§µ‡§æ‡§® (Bhagavan) ‚Äì ‚Äò‡§≠‚Äô stands for Bhoomi or Earth '‡§ó' stands for Gagan or Space ‚Äò‡§µ‚Äô stands for Vayu or Air ‚Äò‡§Ü‚Äô stands for Agni or Fire ‚Äò‡§®‚Äô stands for Neer or Water Bhaga means ‚Äúopulence‚Äù or ‚Äúassets,‚Äù and van means ‚Äúone who possesses.‚Äù Because God owns everything, He is called Bhagavan. The Vedic sage Parashar has defined Bhagavan as the one who possesses in full these assets: beauty, wealth, fame, strength, knowledge, and renunciation. The Learned Know the Absolute Truth call this non-dual substance Bramha, Paramatma or Bhagavan. Om Namo Narayana

#newdaynewchapter Ever wondered why is it that we worship Lord Ganesh first! According to the Ganapati Upanishad, he appeared even before the creation of nature (prakriti) and consciousness (purusha). This is an important link as to why he's is worshiped before beginning any task. According to the yogic perspective, anything we do has to fall under one of the two categories: material or spiritual. It's believed that Lord Ganesh rules the 'Muladhara chakra' of our body. 'Muladhara' is the interface between the material and the spiritual worlds. He controls both these worlds. He gives us material enjoyments in this world and liberates us from endless cycle of birth and death. According to yogic principles, our material life and spiritual journey starts from the 'Muladhara' chakra which is controlled by him. The head of Lord Ganesh symbolizes the atma or soul, which is considered the ultimate reality of humanity and his human body symbolizes Maya, the trappings of earthly existence. Gana‚Äô means category. Everything we perceive through our senses or mind can be expressed in terms of category. The principle from which all these have manifested themselves is Ganapati, the Lord of categories. In effect, it means origin of whole creation, God Himself. Sanskrit word to denote elephant is ‚ÄòGaja‚Äô. Hence the name Gajanan or Gajamukha for Ganapati. But the word ‚ÄòGaja‚Äô has a deeper connotation. ‚ÄòGa‚Äô indicates ‚ÄòGati‚Äô, the final goal towards which the entire creation is moving. ‚ÄòJa‚Äô stands for ‚ÄòJanma‚Äô or birth or origin. Hence ‚ÄòGaja‚Äô signifies God from whom the worlds have come out and towards whom they are progressing, to be ultimately dissolved in Him. The elephant head is thus purely symbolical and points to this truth. The elephant-human form of Ganapati is iconographical representation of great Vedantic dictum, ‚Äòtat-twam-asi'(which means you the apparently limited individual are in essence the Cosmic Truth, the Absolute).Elephant stands for the cosmic, human stands for individual. It's believed that sage Vyasa requested Lord Ganesh to write Mahabharata as he recited it. He decided to do it after Vyasa agreed to recite it without any interruptions and Vyasa, in turn, made him promise he would understand what was being said before he wrote it. His popularity isn‚Äôt restricted to Hinduism.He appears as Buddhist God Vinayaka in Mahayana Buddhism too and is often seen dancing. He has distinct regional characteristics in Tibet, China,Japan.Earliest stone statue of Elephant God in China dates back to as AD 531. Indonesia prints Lord Ganesh on its 20,000 Rupiah note. Indonesia has strong cultural ties with India and Hinduism. Hinduism is practiced by 1.7% of total population, and 83.5% in Bali as of 2010 census. It is one of the dix official religions of Indonesia. Jay Sari Ganesh
